channel.title: Multiple thread owners - Golden idea
channel.description:
Personally I think this idea is amazing, and it just came to mind. If you don't feel the same way that's fine, leave constructive criticism and we'll see what everyone thinks. Anyways enough of the intro, now to the idea:
So how about an option while creating a new thread that allows the creator of the thread give multiple 'edit' permissions to several people. It's like 3:18 am so if that babbling didn't make any sense to you, let me just say it in example form.
Let's say (real scenario) me and Ares_ are developing a server and we post a thread in the server development thread. Ares is offline for a day and I may wanna add a poll/edit some things on the main thread. Well I can't do that until he gets back, which is frustrating to me, because it's really important. This can all be made possible if he grants me 'edit' permissions in the thread. Now whether SMF limits this to being possible or not, I think it's worth a shot. I'm just gonna leave a nice little poll on top for you users to vote on.

item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:57, topic:525313”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=661562.msg4422516#msg4422516 date=1399153526]
Also, another point:
So lets say this went through. You post a server advert or whatever. Someone on the team edits the post and adds something that’s against the rules. Then you edit the topic for an update. You didn’t see the bad content, but it now says you were the last one to edit, and not your partner. The post gets reported. A staff see’s the report log, reads it, and infracts you accordingly. You login and see you’ve been infracted for what looked like to be nothing, but turns out it was your teammates fault. gg.
[/quote]Considering this would only be enabled in the development sections, what exactly would a teammate put in that would be breaking the rules? All I can think of would be like an advertisement link, but we don’t infract for those most of the time we just remove it and post telling them they cant advertise in development topics.[/quote]
It’s just a scenario.

I’m not seeing why this is a big deal. If people share ownership of a topic then let them take personal responsibility for that. If it results in defacement of the topic then that’s not particularly cool, but it’s hardly the end of the world.

The real question that should be asked is 'Is this going to add value to the forum?'
For the vast majority of users, it won’t. With that in mind, administrator time is better spent elsewhere.
